head.title: A Bill of Rights in England

hedline.hl1: A Bill of Rights in England

block.p: England made the European Convention on Human Rights part of domestic law, giving ordinary citizens their first American-style bill of rights ever. Civil libertarians praised the move as the most important change to the British constitutional system in more than 300 years, since the 1689 Bill of Rights limited the monarch's power in relation to Parliament. The new list, which spells out the freedoms of individuals rather than legislators, includes the right to privacy and the right to freedom of expression.

Meanwhile, England's courts braced for legal challenges to myriad domestic laws governing health, the news media, and the criminal justice system, among others, under articles of the convention. Scotland incorporated the Human Rights Act into its law this year.
